description: Cloudflare Tunnel (cloudflared) monitoring — tunnel capacity & scaling, traffic, QUIC transport, connections, latency, edge locations, RPC operations, process resources

panels.title: Requests/sec
panels.description: Rate of HTTP requests proxied through the tunnel.

panels.title: Error Rate %
panels.description: Percentage of requests that resulted in an error proxying to origin.

panels.title: HA Connections
panels.description: Number of active high-availability QUIC connections to Cloudflare edge. Each cloudflared replica establishes 4 HA connections to different edge servers for redundancy.

panels.title: Concurrent Requests
panels.description: Number of requests currently being proxied through the tunnel concurrently.

panels.title: Stream Errors/sec
panels.description: Rate of failures establishing proxy connections to origin. Non-zero indicates origin connectivity problems.

panels.title: Version
panels.description: Running cloudflared version. Sourced from the build_info metric labels.

panels.title: Config Version
panels.description: Remote configuration version from Cloudflare dashboard. Increments when tunnel config is updated.

panels.title: Registrations
panels.description: Total successful tunnel registration events. Should equal 4 × number of replicas after startup.

panels.title: Active TCP Sessions
panels.description: Concurrent TCP sessions being proxied (e.g. SSH, private network access). Not used for HTTP tunnel traffic.

panels.title: Active UDP Sessions
panels.description: Concurrent UDP sessions being proxied (e.g. private DNS, WARP traffic). DNS queries hold a port for 5 seconds.

panels.title: Heartbeat Retries
panels.description: Unacknowledged heartbeat count. Non-zero indicates connectivity issues between cloudflared and the edge.

panels.title: Total Requests
panels.description: Cumulative total of all requests proxied since the process started.

panels.title: Tunnel Capacity & Scaling
panels.description: Capacity estimation for both HTTP-only tunnels (QUIC streams) and WARP/private network tunnels (TCP/UDP port-based). Based on https://developers.cloudflare.com/cloudflare-one/networks/connectors/cloudflare-tunnel/configure-tunnels/tunnel-availability/system-requirements/

panels.title: Concurrent Requests
panels.description: In-flight HTTP requests across all tunnels. This is the primary load indicator for HTTP-only tunnels. Each concurrent request uses one QUIC stream. High values indicate slow origins or high traffic — consider adding replicas.

panels.title: HTTP Requests/sec
panels.description: HTTP request throughput. For HTTP-only tunnels, this is the main scaling metric. Each request is multiplexed over QUIC streams on the 4 HA connections — no ephemeral port consumed on the host.
HTTP request rate and concurrency over time. For HTTP-only tunnels, these are the primary scaling signals. Rising concurrency with flat request rate means increasing origin latency.
panels.title: HTTP Throughput & Concurrency
TCP Port Capacity Used
panels.description: Estimated TCP port utilization. Only relevant for WARP/private network tunnels (SSH, RDP, etc.) — HTTP tunnel traffic uses QUIC streams instead of host ports. TCP ports release almost instantly; at 50,000 ports you'd need 50,001 sustained req/s to exhaust capacity.

panels.title: UDP Port Capacity Used
panels.description: Estimated UDP port utilization. Only relevant for WARP/private network tunnels (private DNS, WARP UDP). DNS queries hold a port for ~5 seconds; at 50,000 ports with 5s timeout, max is 10,000 DNS queries/sec.

Port capacity utilization for WARP/private network traffic. 0% is normal for HTTP-only tunnels — HTTP requests use QUIC streams, not host ports. Only non-zero when proxying TCP sessions (SSH/RDP) or UDP sessions (private DNS/WARP).
panels.title: TCP/UDP Port Capacity % Over Time

options.content:
## Tunnel Scaling Reference

Based on [Cloudflare tunnel system requirements](https://developers.cloudflare.com/cloudflare-one/networks/connectors/cloudflare-tunnel/configure-tunnels/tunnel-availability/system-requirements/):

### Two types of tunnel traffic

| Traffic Type | Bottleneck | Key Metric |
|---|---|---|
| **HTTP requests** (most common) | QUIC streams over 4 HA connections, CPU, memory | Concurrent Requests, Requests/sec |
| **WARP / Private Network** (TCP/UDP) | Host ephemeral ports | TCP/UDP Port Capacity % |

HTTP-only tunnels (like Cloudflare CDN → origin) do **not** consume host ports — requests are multiplexed over QUIC streams. The port-based capacity calculator only applies to WARP/Zero Trust private network access.

### Resource recommendations

| Resource | Recommendation |
|---|---|
| **Replicas** | ≥ 2 per location for redundancy |
| **CPU / RAM** | 4 cores / 4 GB minimum per host |
| **Ports** | 50,000 per host (`net.ipv4.ip_local_port_range = 11000 60999`) — WARP only |
| **ulimit -n** | ≥ 70,000 open file descriptors |

### Port capacity limits (WARP/private network only)

| Traffic Type | Max Sustained / replica | Port Hold Time |
|---|---|---|
| **TCP requests** | 50,000 req/s | ~instant release |
| **DNS (UDP)** | 10,000 queries/s | 5 seconds |
| **Non-DNS UDP** | 50,000 concurrent | connection duration |

### When to scale

| Signal | Action |
|---|---|
| Concurrent requests consistently > 50 | Add replica |
| TCP/UDP port capacity > 60% | Add replica |
| Proxy connect latency p95 rising | Check origin health, then add replica |
| HA connections < 4 per replica | Investigate connectivity |

### ⚠ Scaling limitations

cloudflared has **no auto-scaling capability or integration**. You can add replicas manually for HA, but **scaling down will break active eyeball connections** pinned to that replica — there is no graceful drain. Replicas within the same tunnel are strictly for **high availability, not load balancing** — Cloudflare does not distribute requests evenly across replicas of the same tunnel.

For true horizontal scaling with controlled scale-down, run **multiple discrete tunnels** behind a load balancer (e.g. Cloudflare Load Balancing or an internal LB), so each tunnel can be drained and removed independently.

panels.title: Scaling Guidelines
panels.description: Quick reference for Cloudflare tunnel sizing — covers both HTTP-only and WARP/private network tunnels.
Rate of requests proxied vs errors. Errors are requests that failed to reach origin (connection refused, timeout, TLS mismatch, etc.).
panels.title: Requests / sec

panels.description: HTTP response status code distribution. Codes are from origin responses proxied back through the tunnel. 502/503 typically indicate origin unreachable.
panels.title: Response Status Codes

panels.description: Percentage of requests resulting in proxy errors. Sustained rates above 1% warrant investigation — check origin health, TLS config, and DNS resolution.
panels.title: Error Rate %

panels.description: Stacked view of response code volume over time. Useful for seeing the proportion of success vs error responses.
panels.title: Response Codes (Stacked)

panels.description: Number of active high-availability QUIC connections. Each cloudflared instance maintains 4 connections to different Cloudflare edge servers. A drop below 4 per replica means degraded redundancy.
panels.title: HA Connections

panels.description: In-flight requests per tunnel instance. Spikes correlate with slow origins or large request payloads.
panels.title: Concurrent Requests per Tunnel

panels.description: Active and new TCP sessions. TCP is used for private network access (SSH, RDP, etc.), not HTTP tunnel traffic.
panels.title: TCP Sessions

panels.description: Active and new UDP sessions. Primarily private DNS resolution. Each DNS query holds a port for 5 seconds.
panels.title: UDP Sessions

panels.description: Rate of failures establishing proxy connections to origin. Causes include connection refused, DNS failure, or TLS handshake errors.
panels.title: Proxy Stream Errors

panels.description: Unacknowledged heartbeat count per tunnel. Non-zero values indicate the edge hasn't responded to keepalive pings — possible network disruption or edge congestion.
panels.title: Heartbeat Retries

panels.description: ICMP traffic proxied through the tunnel. Used for diagnostic ping through private networks.
panels.title: ICMP Requests & Replies

panels.description: Cumulative successful tunnel registrations. Should be 4 × replicas after initial startup. Increases indicate reconnections (e.g. after pod restarts or edge failovers).
panels.title: Tunnel Registrations
Edge Locations
panels.description: Which Cloudflare edge data centers the tunnel connections terminate at.

panels.title: Active Edge Server Locations
panels.description: Current edge PoP for each HA connection (value=1 means current, 0=previous). Connection IDs 0-3 map to the 4 HA connections per replica.
Remote configuration version over time. Step changes indicate config pushes from the Cloudflare dashboard (e.g. ingress rule updates).
panels.title: Config Version Over Time
QUIC Transport
panels.description: QUIC protocol metrics for the connections between cloudflared and Cloudflare edge. Each HA connection (conn_index 0-3) is an independent QUIC connection.

Round-trip time from cloudflared to the Cloudflare edge per QUIC connection. Smoothed RTT is the EWMA used by congestion control. Min RTT is the floor. Sudden increases indicate network path degradation.
panels.title: QUIC RTT to Edge

panels.description: QUIC congestion window size per connection. Larger windows = more data in flight. The window grows during slow start and shrinks on packet loss. A persistently small window indicates congestion.
panels.title: QUIC Congestion Window

panels.description: Aggregate QUIC-level throughput across all connections. 'Sent' = data from cloudflared to edge (origin responses). 'Received' = data from edge to cloudflared (client requests).
panels.title: QUIC Bytes Sent / Received

panels.description: Per-connection QUIC throughput. Uneven distribution may indicate one edge PoP is handling more traffic (e.g. due to Cloudflare's Anycast routing).
panels.title: QUIC Bytes by Connection

panels.description: Rate of lost QUIC packets by connection and reason. 'reordering' = detected via packet number gaps. 'timeout' = detected via RTO. Sustained loss degrades throughput and increases latency.
panels.title: QUIC Packet Loss

panels.description: QUIC congestion control state per connection. States: 0=SlowStart, 1=CongestionAvoidance, 2=Recovery, 3=ApplicationLimited. ApplicationLimited (3) is normal for low-traffic tunnels — means the bottleneck is traffic volume, not network capacity.
panels.title: QUIC Congestion State

panels.description: Discovered path MTU and maximum UDP payload size per connection. Default QUIC MTU is ~1375 bytes. A drop could indicate path MTU blackhole or network reconfiguration.
panels.title: QUIC MTU / Max Payload

panels.description: Rate of QUIC frames sent by type. 'Stream' frames carry actual data. 'Ping' frames are keepalives. 'ResetStream'/'StopSending' indicate cancelled requests. 'StreamDataBlocked'/'DataBlocked' indicate flow control pressure.
panels.title: QUIC Frames Sent

panels.description: Rate of QUIC frames received by type. High 'Ping' rate is normal (edge keepalives). 'MaxData'/'MaxStreamData' are flow control updates. 'ResetStream' from edge may indicate request cancellation by client.
panels.title: QUIC Frames Received
Latency
panels.description: Origin-facing latency measured by cloudflared. Proxy connect = time to establish connection to origin. RPC = control plane operations.

Time to establish and acknowledge connections to origin, in milliseconds. Includes DNS resolution, TCP handshake, and TLS handshake to origin. High p99 may indicate DNS resolution delays or origin connection pool exhaustion.
panels.title: Proxy Connect Latency

panels.description: Latency of RPC calls initiated by cloudflared (e.g. register_connection). These are control plane operations, not data plane. High latency here affects tunnel registration/reconnection speed.
panels.title: RPC Client Latency

panels.description: Latency of RPC calls served by cloudflared (e.g. update_configuration from edge). High values may indicate slow config processing.
panels.title: RPC Server Latency

panels.description: Distribution of proxy connect latency across histogram buckets. Shows the shape of the latency distribution — bimodal patterns may indicate DNS cache hits/misses.
panels.title: Proxy Connect Latency Heatmap (rate)
RPC Operations
panels.description: Control plane RPC operations between cloudflared and Cloudflare edge.
Rate of RPC calls initiated by cloudflared. 'registration/register_connection' happens at startup and reconnection. Frequent calls may indicate unstable connections.
panels.title: RPC Client Operations

panels.description: Rate of RPC calls served by cloudflared. 'config/update_configuration' is triggered by Cloudflare dashboard changes. Frequent unexpected calls may indicate config flapping.
panels.title: RPC Server Operations
Process Resources
panels.description: System resource usage of the cloudflared process. Key limits: CPU cores (resource limits), memory (resource limits), file descriptors (ulimit -n, should be ≥70,000).
CPU usage as fraction of one core. 1.0 = one full core. Compare against resource limits to assess headroom.
panels.title: CPU Usage

panels.description: RSS = total process memory. Go Heap = active Go allocations. Heap Idle = memory returned to runtime but not OS. RSS is the metric to compare against k8s memory limits.
panels.title: Memory Usage

panels.description: Process-level network throughput. TX = data sent to origins + edge. RX = data received from edge + origins. Should correlate with QUIC bytes but includes non-tunnel traffic (metrics scrapes, etc.).
panels.title: Network I/O

panels.description: Number of active Go goroutines. Correlates with concurrent requests. A sustained increase without corresponding traffic may indicate goroutine leaks.
panels.title: Goroutines

panels.description: Open vs maximum file descriptors. Cloudflare recommends ulimit -n ≥ 70,000. If Open approaches Max, connections will fail. In Kubernetes, check the pod's securityContext or the node's /proc/sys/fs/file-max.
panels.title: Open File Descriptors

panels.description: Rate of time spent in Go garbage collection (stop-the-world pauses). High GC pressure correlates with high allocation rate. Should be negligible (<1% of wall time).
panels.title: GC Duration

panels.description: Number of live heap-allocated Go objects. Correlates with concurrent connections and requests. Rapid growth indicates memory pressure.
panels.title: Heap Objects

panels.description: Rate of Go heap allocations. High allocation rate drives more frequent GC. Correlates with request rate — each proxied request allocates buffers.
panels.title: Memory Allocation Rate

list.description: Number of ephemeral ports available to cloudflared (default: 50000 per Cloudflare recommendation, set via net.ipv4.ip_local_port_range)
list.label: Available Ports
list.name: available_ports

list.description: DNS UDP session timeout in seconds (default: 5s per Cloudflare docs). Each DNS query holds an ephemeral port for this duration.
list.label: DNS Timeout (s)
list.name: dns_timeout

title: Cloudflare Tunnel
